access.description: The registered URL uses an obfuscated random string path (sldkjljieo0935jljsrnfkl) that is not discoverable from the NextGen website navigation. Despite this, the URL returns HTTP 200 directly with no redirects and no anti-bot protection. The page is server-rendered HTML (Sitecore CMS) that works fine via curl without JavaScript. The PDF data dictionary linked from the page has x-robots-tag: noindex, nofollow, actively preventing search engine discovery. The combination of obfuscated URL + noindex makes this documentation effectively hidden from anyone who doesn't already have the URL.

product_context.description: NextGen Healthcare (NASDAQ: NXGN) is a major ambulatory EHR and practice management vendor serving physician practices of all sizes across 40+ specialties. The certified module 'NextGen Enterprise EHR' is one component of a much broader product suite that includes Practice Management (billing, scheduling, registration, claims), Patient Experience (patient portal with secure text messaging, online scheduling, payments), Revenue Cycle Management (clearinghouse, claims processing, denial management), NextGen Office (cloud-based EHR/PM for smaller practices), Direct Messaging, and Mirth Connect (interoperability engine). The homepage describes the platform as 'Intelligent EHR, PM, Patient Experience, and RCMS.' The patient portal explicitly offers secure text messaging — a customer quote on the website states patients are 'sending us lots of messages, so that they don't have to call us on the phone.' The PM solution has been ranked #1 by Black Book Research for 9 consecutive years. The full product clearly stores billing/claims data, insurance/eligibility data, scheduling data, patient portal messages, and documents in addition to clinical data.
product_context.broader_product_name: NextGen Healthcare Platform (Enterprise EHR + PM + Patient Experience + RCM)

export_approach.description: The export approach varies by product. NextGen Enterprise EHR uses a native database export — the 10,875-page data dictionary documents the schema of internal database tables with SQL Server data types (char, varchar, uniqueidentifier, datetime, int, etc.). This is a direct dump of the EHR's clinical database tables, which is the gold standard approach. However, the export appears to be limited to the EHR database only and does not include Practice Management (PM) database tables for billing, claims, payments, A/R, or scheduling. NextGen Office exports as a ZIP archive containing CCDA XML, CSV, binary files (images/PDFs), and HTML files — a mixed approach. NextGen Direct Messaging exports as ZIP with CDA XML and binary files. Mirth Connect exports messages with attachments in XML format with base64-encoded attachments. Of the four products, only Enterprise EHR has detailed schema documentation; the other three have only brief format descriptions.

documentation_quality.description: The NextGen Enterprise EHR data dictionary is extremely detailed at the schema and field level — 10,875 pages documenting approximately 5,077 unique database tables with full column names and SQL Server data types (char, varchar, uniqueidentifier, datetime, int, smallint, text, bit, etc.). Each table entry includes column names, data types, default values, and not-null constraints. However, the documentation is ONLY provided as a massive 29 MB PDF, which is very difficult to work with programmatically. There is no HTML viewer, no downloadable CSV/JSON schema, no search functionality. The documentation does NOT include: value set definitions (what codes mean), relationships between tables (no foreign key documentation), sample data, or narrative descriptions of what each table contains. The table names use internal naming conventions — many are specialty-specific prefixes (CARD_ for cardiology, AINF_ for ancillary/infusion, HPI_ for history of present illness, bh_ for behavioral health, etc.) that require domain knowledge to interpret. The other three products (Office, Direct Messaging, Mirth Connect) have almost no documentation — just a few sentences describing the file format of the export with no schema detail.

ehi_coverage.overall_assessment: The NextGen Enterprise EHR export is massively detailed on the clinical side — 5,077 tables spanning 40+ medical specialties with deep clinical template data. The strength is clearly clinical documentation: specialty-specific encounter templates for cardiology, behavioral health, OB/GYN, orthopedics, pediatrics, ophthalmology, ENT, GI, pulmonology, dermatology, rheumatology, and many more. However, there is a significant gap: the export appears to be limited to the EHR's clinical database and does not include the Practice Management (PM) database. No dedicated billing transaction tables, claims tables, payment ledger tables, accounts receivable tables, or insurance enrollment tables appear in the data dictionary. The billing-related content that IS present consists of clinical billing references (superbill templates, fee sheet CPT/DX associations, one NGWEB_STATEMENT_PAYMENT table for portal payments), not the full revenue cycle data. Given that NextGen's PM solution is a core component of the broader product — ranked #1 by Black Book Research — and stores extensive billing, claims, scheduling, and insurance data, this appears to be a substantial coverage gap. Similarly, patient portal secure messages appear absent, despite the product explicitly offering this functionality. The other three products (Office, Direct Messaging, Mirth Connect) have minimal documentation, making it impossible to fully assess their export coverage.

clinical.evidence: Extremely strong clinical coverage across 5,077 tables. Includes: diagnoses/problems (Diagnostics_, OB_Diagnostics_, info_chronic_problems_), medications (MedicationChanges_, Associate_Medications_), allergies (AllergyMaster_, Allergy_Table_, CARD_Allergies_), vitals (vital_signs_ and 10+ specialty variants), labs/results (lab-related tables, CARD result wizards for various tests), immunizations (Immunization_Rec_, adult_immunizations_), procedures (CARD_Procedures_, proc_ tables), clinical notes (CARD_ProgressNote_, CARD_ChartNotes_, ChartNotesExtPop_), assessments (Assessment_, Assessment_Info_), care plans (FollowUp_Plans_, DCE_CCMPlanOfCare_), family history (Family_Hx_Dtl_, CARD_FamilyHistory_), social history (Social_Hx_, adult_social_history_), problem lists, advance directives (advance_directives_, bh_psych_adv_directives_), and extensive specialty-specific templates for 40+ specialties including cardiology (250 CARD_ tables), behavioral health (177 bh_ tables), OB/GYN, orthopedics, ophthalmology, ENT, GI, pulmonology, dermatology, and more. The depth of clinical specialty content is among the most comprehensive seen.

secure_messages.evidence: Searched for message/inbox/communication/chat/portal/secure/correspondence across all 5,077 table names and the full extracted text. Found: Communication_summary_ (minimal columns), Prov_communication_ and Provider_communication_ (provider-to-provider communication records with fields like txt_comm_to, txt_comments, txt_regarding), sub_provider_communication_, FollowUp_Communication_, portal_document_posting_, portal_records_, and error_message_in_response_ (e-prescribing error messages). None of these appear to be patient portal secure messaging tables. The Prov_communication_ tables are provider-to-provider records, not patient-provider messages. The portal tables relate to document posting, not messaging. NextGen's product explicitly advertises 'Secure text messaging' in the patient portal and a customer quote describes patients 'sending us lots of messages.' The absence of patient-provider secure messaging tables from the export is a significant gap.

billing_financial.evidence: Found only clinical billing references, not full Practice Management financial data. Present: ainf_feesheet_cpt_dx_ (CPT/diagnosis associations on fee sheets), AINF_PT_feesheet_ and variants (physical therapy fee sheets), TOAsuperbill_ and card_submit_superbill_ (superbill submission templates), onc_chemo_superbill_ (oncology chemotherapy superbill), TelephoneBilling_ (telephone billing comments), NGWEB_STATEMENT_PAYMENT (portal statement payment with AMOUNT_PAID, TRANSACTION_ID, CARD_NUMBER), claim_based_reporting_ (CQM claim reporting, not actual claims), and DCE_CCMBillingQueue_. There are column-level references to copay (actFeeCoPay, encounter_copay_amt, copay_ind), deductible (deductible_amt), balance_due, txt_charge_amount, and a few price fields (Unit_Price, cash_price10, retail_price6). However, there are NO dedicated claims tables, payment ledger tables, accounts receivable tables, transaction history tables, adjustment tables, EOB tables, or billing statement tables that would be expected from a full Practice Management system. The PM product is a major component of NextGen Healthcare — ranked #1 by Black Book for billing — yet its transaction-level data appears absent from the EHI export.

insurance_coverage.evidence: Found insurance-related columns scattered across clinical tables (prim_ins, sec_ins_plan_nr, sec_ins_policy_nbr, payer_id, person_payer_id, insurance_name, plan_name, group_nbr, coverage_id, eligibility_id, insurance_type_code) and one table IORTSinsurance_forms_xpo2_ and IORTSdemographics_ (which includes prim_ins, sec_ins fields). Also found AINF_Payer_Override_Config_ and CMSICDCoverage_. However, there are no dedicated insurance enrollment tables, eligibility verification tables, authorization/pre-certification tracking tables (beyond clinical workflow ainf_pre_cert tables), payer master tables, or benefits detail tables. The insurance data present is embedded within clinical encounter contexts, not as standalone insurance/coverage entities. The bh_authorizations_ table exists for behavioral health but appears specialty-specific.

appointments_scheduling.evidence: Found multiple appointment and scheduling-related tables: appointment_status_ (with txt_room, txt_status), appointment_waitlist (with person_id, waitlist_id), patient_futur_appointment_ (with appnt_date, details, event), pat_apt_status_hx_ (appointment status history with txt_appt_time, txt_room), Asc_scheduling_questions_, and numerous IORTS scheduling tables (IORTSsurg_sched_coor_, IORTSClock_appt_w_, IORTSClock_resched1_). Also encounter-related visit tables across specialties (AINF_PT_single_visit_, CARD_DoctorVisits_, CARD_HospitalVisit_). While scheduling data is present, it appears to be clinical-side scheduling (encounter-linked) rather than the full PM scheduling module with time slots, resource calendars, and booking management.

documents_images.evidence: Found document and image-related tables: Document_Library_, chm_document_library_, attachment_details_, ImageCapture_, Image_Capture_, Image_lookup_, derm_image_body_, derm_image_face_, gi_scope_images_, documentation_log_comments_, portal_document_posting_, cm_documentation_, cm_ext_document_. The landing page explicitly states 'While certain EHI, such as images, documents, reports, and audio files are referenced in the tables, they are located in the corresponding file folders in the extract.' This confirms that binary files (images, documents, reports, audio) are exported as separate files alongside the database tables.

audit_trails.evidence: Found tables named with audit/log/tracking terminology but they are primarily clinical workflow logs, not system access audit trails: audit_ (has chk_charges_submitted, chk_dataPresent — charge submission tracking, not access logging), PHI_Log_ (PHI disclosure log with patient comments), PGH_audit_log_ext_ (patient-generated health data audit with accessed_by, Audit_log_date, Audit_log_time — closest to an access log but specific to patient-generated data), Prov_comm_audit_ext_, CARD_DisclosureLog_, Chart_Tracking_, Lab_Action_Log_, Provider_Action_Log_, Provider_Test_Action_Log_. Most tables have created_by/modified_by integer fields (user IDs) and timestamps, providing some change tracking. However, there are no dedicated system access audit trail tables documenting who accessed which patient record, when, and what they viewed — the type of audit trail that would typically be maintained in a separate audit database for HIPAA compliance.

issues: The export appears to cover only the EHR clinical database — the Practice Management (PM) database with billing transactions, claims, payments, accounts receivable, and full scheduling data appears to be absent, despite PM being a core component of the NextGen Healthcare product.
Patient portal secure messaging data appears absent from the export despite NextGen explicitly advertising 'Secure text messaging' in their patient portal and customers actively using this feature.

Only the NextGen Enterprise EHR has a detailed data dictionary (10,875-page PDF); the other three certified products (NextGen Office, Direct Messaging, Mirth Connect) have only brief prose descriptions with no schema documentation.
The data dictionary is provided only as a 29 MB PDF with no machine-readable alternative (HTML, CSV, JSON), making it extremely difficult to programmatically analyze or search the 5,077 tables.

The URL uses an obfuscated random string path (sldkjljieo0935jljsrnfkl) and the PDF has x-robots-tag: noindex, nofollow — the documentation is intentionally hidden from search engines and website navigation.
No foreign key relationships, value set definitions, or table descriptions are provided — understanding what each table contains requires domain expertise and inference from column names.
Insurance/coverage data appears only as scattered fields within clinical encounter tables, not as standalone insurance enrollment or eligibility entities.
System access audit trails (who viewed which patient record, when) are not present in the export; only clinical workflow logs and change tracking timestamps exist.

downloaded_files.description: NextGen Enterprise EHR database dictionary documenting approximately 5,077 database tables with column names, SQL Server data types, default values, and not-null constraints. 10,875 pages. Covers the EHR clinical database schema as of June 27, 2025.

The EHI Data Export landing page covering all four certified products (Enterprise EHR, Office, Direct Messaging, Mirth Connect) with format descriptions and a link to the Enterprise EHR database dictionary.

summary: NextGen Healthcare provides a massive 10,875-page database dictionary for the Enterprise EHR covering ~5,077 tables with excellent clinical depth across 40+ medical specialties. However, the export appears to cover only the EHR clinical database, not the Practice Management database that stores billing transactions, claims, payments, and full scheduling data — a significant gap given that PM is a core product component. Patient portal secure messaging, full insurance enrollment data, and system access audit trails also appear absent. The documentation is only available as a 29 MB PDF with no machine-readable alternative, and the URL is obfuscated with noindex tags to prevent discovery.
notes: The table naming conventions reveal the specialty-template architecture: CARD_ (250 tables, cardiology), AINF_ (204 tables, ancillary/infusion/PT), HPI_ (131+ tables, history of present illness), bh_ (177 tables, behavioral health), PEDS_ (51 tables, pediatrics), OB_ (46 tables, obstetrics), ENT_ (28 tables, ear/nose/throat), IORTS_ (65+ tables, orthopedics/surgical), pe_ (185 tables, physical exam), info_ (251 tables, information/utility), tis_ (184 tables), and many more. This specialty-template architecture means the clinical data is extremely rich but also very wide — many tables contain overlapping data for different specialty workflows. The 'created_by' and 'modified_by' integer fields appear on virtually every table, providing basic change attribution but not a comprehensive access audit trail. The page also serves as the documentation hub for NextGen Office, Direct Messaging, and Mirth Connect, but those products have only brief format descriptions (CCDA/CSV for Office, CDA for Direct Messaging, XML for Mirth Connect) with no detailed schema documentation.
